Label: CDC Opioid Mortality
Description: A dataset of drug poisoning deaths at the national, state, and county levels as reported by mortality medical coders, nosologists, and other individuals responsible for processing vital records.
Pub1: Cornaggia, K. R., Hund, J., Nguyen, G., & Ye, Z. (2020). Opioid Crisis Effects On Municipal Finance. SSRN, (3448082). Retrieved from https://papers.ssrn.com/abstract=3448082
Pub2: Anders, J. (2019). Medicaid, Marijuana and Opioids: Is Prescription Access to Blame? Rochester, NY. Retrieved from https://papers.ssrn.com/abstract=3247989
Pub3: Deiana, C., Giua, L., & Nisticò, R. (2019). The Economics Behind the Epidemic: Afghan Opium Price and Prescription Opioids in the US. Rochester, NY. Retrieved from https://papers.ssrn.com/abstract=3352893

Label: TEDS admissions
Description: A national data system of annual admissions to substance abuse treatment facilities because substance abuse treatment programs are required by state laws to report their publically-funded admissions to the state. Some states also collect privately-funded admissions from facilities that receive public funding.
Pub1: Smith, R. A. (2020). The Effects of Medical Marijuana Dispensaries on Adverse Opioid Outcomes. Economic Inquiry, 58(2), 569–588. https://doi.org/10.1111/ecin.12825
Pub2: Meinhofer, A., & Witman, A. E. (2018). The role of health insurance on treatment for opioid use disorders: Evidence from the Affordable Care Act Medicaid expansion. Journal of Health Economics, 60, 177–197. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jhealeco.2018.06.004
Pub3: Powell, D., Pacula, R. L., & Jacobson, M. (2015). Do Medical Marijuana Laws Reduce Addictions and Deaths Related to Pain Killers? National Bureau of Economic Research Working Paper Series, 21345. https://doi.org/10.3386/w21345

Label: NAS
Description: A nationally representative survey of U.S. adults (age 18+) involving alcohol questions and repeated at approximately 5-year intervals since the 1960s.
Pub1: Karriker-Jaffe, K. J., Subbaraman, M. S., Greenfield, T. K., & Kerr, W. C. (2018). Contribution of alcohol and drug co-use to substance use problems: Data from a nationally-representative sample of US adults who have never been to treatment. NAD Nordic Studies on Alcohol and Drugs, 35(6), 428–442. https://doi.org/10.1177/1455072518806122
Pub2: Parish, W. J., Aldridge, A., Allaire, B., Ekwueme, D. U., Poehler, D., Guy, G. P., Thomas, C. C., & Trogdon, J. G. (2017). A new methodological approach to adjust alcohol exposure distributions to improve the estimation of alcohol-attributable fractions. Addiction, 112(11), 2053–2063. https://doi.org/10.1111/add.13880

Label: NSDUH
Description: A yearly national survey since 1971 about tobacco, alcohol, and drug use, mental health, and other health-related issues.
Pub1: Mulligan, C. B. (2020). Prices and Federal Policies in Opioid Markets. https://doi.org/10.3386/w26812
Pub2: Powell, D., Alpert, A., & Pacula, R. L. (2019). A Transitioning Epidemic: How The Opioid Crisis Is Driving The Rise In Hepatitis C. Health Affairs, 38(2), 287–294. https://doi.org/10.1377/hlthaff.2018.05232
Pub3: Beheshti, D. (2019). Adverse health effects of abuse?deterrent opioids: Evidence from the reformulation of OxyContin. Health Economics, 28(12), 1449–1461. https://doi.org/10.1002/hec.3944

Label: NPDS
Description: A national dataset of the number of cases involving human or animal poisioning or exposure to poision as reported by poison centers in the U.S.
Data Source: https://aapcc.org/track/opioids; https://piper.filecamp.com/uniq/VvF2ELEL6RwIOqVP.pdf; https://piper.filecamp.com/uniq/DRw83uhg79UetPPw.pdf; https://aapcc.org/data-system; https://piper.filecamp.com/uniq/meDKF2EpE2jsmTOs.pdf (used to calculate # of records; 5753 cases per day times 365)
Pub1: Eluri, M., Spiller, H. A., Casavant, M. J., Chounthirath, T., Conner, K. A., & Smith, G. A. (2018). Analgesic-related medication errors reported to US poison control centers. Pain Medicine (United States), 19(12), 2357–2370. https://doi.org/10.1093/pm/pnx272
Pub2: Sheridan, D. C., Laurie, A., Hendrickson, R. G., Fu, R., Kea, B., & Horowitz, B. Z. (2016). Association of Overall Opioid Prescriptions on Adolescent Opioid Abuse. Journal of Emergency Medicine, 51(5), 485–490. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jemermed.2016.06.049
Pub3: Allen, J. D., Casavant, M. J., Spiller, H. A., Chounthirath, T., Hodges, N. L., & Smith, G. A. (2017). Prescription opioid exposures among children and adolescents in the United States: 2000-2015. Pediatrics, 139(4). https://doi.org/10.1542/peds.2016-3382

Label: MEPS
Description: A national survey of families and individuals, their medical providers, and employers across the U.S. with questions about specific health services, frequency of use of health services, cost of health services, how the health services are pair for, and the cost, scope, and breadth of health insurance held by and available to U.S. workers.
Pub1: Alpert, A. E., Evans, W. N., Lieber, E. M. J., & Powell, D. (2019). Origins of the Opioid Crisis and Its Enduring Impacts. https://doi.org/10.3386/w26500
Pub2: Soni, A. (2019). Health Insurance, Price Changes, and the Demand for Pain Relief Drugs: Evidence from Medicare Part D. Rochester, NY. Retrieved from https://papers.ssrn.com/abstract=3268968
Pub3: Alpert, A., Powell, D., & Pacula, R. L. (2018). Supply-Side Drug Policy in the Presence of Substitutes: Evidence from the Introduction of Abuse-Deterrent Opioids. American Economic Journal: Economic Policy, 10(4), 1–35. https://doi.org/10.1257/pol.20170082

Label: N-SSATs
Description: An annual census of all treatment facilities listed on the I-BHS, an electronic master list of all organized substance abuse treatment faciliies known to the SAMHSA. Information on location, organization, structure, services, and utilization of substance abuse treatment facilities in the U.S. is collected.
Pub1: Grooms, J., & Ortega, A. (2019). Examining Medicaid Expansion and the Treatment of Substance Use Disorders. AEA Papers and Proceedings, 109, 187–192. https://doi.org/10.1257/pandp.20191090
Pub2: Maclean, J. C., & Saloner, B. (2018). Substance Use Treatment Provider Behavior and Healthcare Reform: Evidence from Massachusetts. Health Economics, 27(1), 76–101. https://doi.org/10.1002/hec.3484
Pub3: Harris, K. (2017). The Effect of State Parity Laws on How Providers Treat Substance Use Disorder. Monthly Labor Review, 1b. Retrieved from https://www.questia.com/library/journal/1G1-500009397/the-effect-of-state-parity-laws-on-how-providers-treat

Label: QCEW
Description: Quarterly count of employment and wages reported by employers covering more than 95% of U.S. jobs available at the county, Metropolitan Statistical Area, state and national levels by detailed industry.
Pub1: Currie, J., Jin, J. Y., & Schnell, M. (2018). U.S. Employment and Opioids: Is There a Connection? https://doi.org/10.3386/w24440

Label: TEDS Discharge
Description: A national data system of annual number and characteristics of person discharged from public and private substance abuse treatment programs that receive public funding, as reported by law to state substance abuse agencies by the treatment programs.
Pub1: Askari, M. S., Martins, S. S., & Mauro, P. M. (2020). Medication for opioid use disorder treatment and specialty outpatient substance use treatment outcomes: Differences in retention and completion among opioid-related discharges in 2016. Journal of Substance Abuse Treatment, 114(October 2019), 108028. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jsat.2020.108028
Pub2: Stahler, G. J., Mennis, J., & DuCette, J. P. (2016). Residential and outpatient treatment completion for substance use disorders in the U.S.: Moderation analysis by demographics and drug of choice. Addictive Behaviors, 58, 129–135. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.addbeh.2016.02.030
Pub3: Stahler, G. J., & Mennis, J. (2018). Treatment outcome disparities for opioid users: Are there racial and ethnic differences in treatment completion across large US metropolitan areas? Drug and Alcohol Dependence, 190(July), 170–178. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.drugalcdep.2018.06.006

Label: IPEDS
Description: A national dataset of enrollments, completions and completers, graduation rates, faculty and staff, finances, institutional prices, student financial aid, admissions, and academic libraries as required to disclose by the Higher Education Act of 1965 from every college, university, and technical/vocational institution that participations in the federal student financial aid programs.
Pub1: Aikins, R., Zhang, X., & McCabe, S. E. (2017). Academic Doping: Institutional Policies Regarding Nonmedical use of Prescription Stimulants in U.S. Higher Education. Journal of Academic Ethics, 15(3), 229–243. https://doi.org/10.1007/s10805-017-9291-0

Label: CBP
Description: A national database of annual statistics for businesses with paid employees within the U.S. and U.S. terriroties, taken from the Business Register. Data includes the number of establishments, employment during the week of March 12, first quarter payroll, and annual payroll.
Pub1: Pierce, J. R., & Schott, P. K. (2020). Trade Liberalization and Mortality: Evidence from US Counties. American Economic Review: Insights, 2(1), 47–64. https://doi.org/10.1257/aeri.20180396
Pub2: Bondurant, S. R., Lindo, J. M., & Swensen, I. D. (2018). Substance abuse treatment centers and local crime. Journal of Urban Economics, 104, 124–133. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jue.2018.01.007
Pub3: Dave, D., Deza, M., & Horn, B. P. (2018). Prescription Drug Monitoring Programs, Opioid Abuse, and Crime. https://doi.org/10.3386/w24975

Label: ACS
Description: A monthly national survey sent to a sample of people across the U.S. that asks questions about education, employment, internet access, transportation, etc.
Pub1: Rietveld, C. A., & Patel, P. C. (2020). Prescription opioids and new business establishments. Small Business Economics. https://doi.org/10.1007/s11187-020-00343-x
Pub2: Kaestner, R., & Ziedan, E. (2019). Mortality and Socioeconomic Consequences of Prescription Opioids: Evidence from State Policies. https://doi.org/10.3386/w26135
Pub3: Gihleb, R., Giuntella, O., & Zhang, N. (2019). Prescription Drug Monitoring Programs and Neonatal Outcomes. Rochester, NY. Retrieved from https://papers.ssrn.com/abstract=3495773

Label: Open Payments
Description: A national disclosure program provides detailed information on financial relationships including consulting fees, research grants, travel reimbursements, ownership, and other direct payments from manufacturers to medical practitioners (physicians and teaching hospitals).
Pub1: Li, W., & Zhu, Q. (2019). The Opioid Epidemic and Local Public Financing: Evidence from Municipal Bonds. https://doi.org/10.2139/ssrn.3454026
Pub2: Nguyen, T. D., Bradford, W. D., & Simon, K. I. (2019). How do Opioid Prescribing Restrictions Affect Pharmaceutical Promotion? Lessons from the Mandatory Access Prescription Drug Monitoring Programs. https://doi.org/10.3386/w26356

Label: MEDICAID
Description: A national dataset reported by states for covered outpatient drugs that are paid for by state Medicaid agencies since the start of the Medicaid Drug Rebate Program. The data includes state, drug name, National Drug Code, number of prescriptions, and dollars reimbursed.
Pub1: Abouk, R., Pacula, R. L., & Powell, D. (2019). Association between State Laws Facilitating Pharmacy Distribution of Naloxone and Risk of Fatal Overdose. JAMA Internal Medicine, 179(6), 805–811. https://doi.org/10.1001/jamainternmed.2019.0272

Label: Medicare
Description: A national database of all transactions covered by the Medicare prescription drug plan for both Prescription Drug Plans (PDPs) and Medicare Advantage Prescription Drug Plans (MA-PDs). Variables include service date, produce service ID, quantity dispensed, days supply, cost, payment, and linkage variables.
Pub1: Rhodes, J. (n.d.). Private Health Insurer Incentives and Prescription Opioid Use:  Evidence from Medicare Part D. https://drive.google.com/file/d/1CWeTYQbib7QluDoRwSGoQg5E9gl_vGGe/view
Pub2: Harris, M. C., Kessler, L. M., Murray, M. N., & Glenn, B. (2019). Prescription Opioids and Labor Market Pains: The Effect of Schedule II Opioids on Labor Force Participation and Unemployment. Journal of Human Resources, 1017. https://doi.org/10.3368/jhr.55.4.1017-9093R2
Pub3: Beheshti, D. (2019). The Impact of Opioids on the Labor Market: Evidence from Drug Rescheduling. Retrieved from https://drive.google.com/file/d/1D0XdzcRRZuG3c7WoouaoiOw2q_IH4Rcr/view?usp=embed_facebook

Label: ARCOS
Description: An automated, comprehaensive drug reporting system which monitors the flow of DEA controlled substances from their point of manufacture through commercial distribution channels to point of sale or distribution of the dispensing/retail level.
Pub1: US Department of Justice, Drug Enforcement Administration, Division of Diversion Control. 2019. ARCOS retail drug summary report. Available at https://www. deadiversion.usdoj.gov/ arcos/ retail_drug_summary/index.html (accessed on 6 October 2019)
Pub2: Buchmueller, T. C., Carey, C. M., & Meille, G. (2019). How Well Do Doctors Know Their Patients? Evidence from a Mandatory Access Prescription Drug Monitoring Program. https://doi.org/10.3386/w26159
Pub3: D’Lima, W., & Thibodeau, M. (2019). Health Crisis and Housing Market Effects - Evidence from the U.S. Opioid Epidemic. SSRN, (ID 3456404). Retrieved from https://papers.ssrn.com/abstract=3456404

Label: CDC Prescription
Description: The source for all prescribing data comes from IQVIA Xponent, which is based on a sample of approximately 49,900 retail (non-hospital) pharmacies, which dispense nearly 92% of all retail prescriptions in the U.S. This database does not include mail order prescriptions.
Pub1: Aliprantis, D., Fee, K., & Schweitzer, M. (2019). Opioids and the Labor Market. Rochester, NY. Retrieved from https://papers.ssrn.com/abstract=3179068
Pub2: CouncilEconAdvisors. (2019). The Role of Opioid Prices in the Evolving Opioid Crisis. Retrieved from https://www.whitehouse.gov/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/The-Role-of-Opioid-Prices-in-the-Evolving-Opioid-Crisis.pdf
Pub3: Metcalf, G. E., & Wang, Q. (2019). Abandoned by Coal, Swallowed by Opioids? National Bureau of Economic Research Working Paper Series, (26551). https://doi.org/10.3386/w26551

Label: NAMSDL
Description: NAMSDL, originally President's Commission on Model State Drug Laws, was established to create model codes of laws to help states effectively address alcohol and other drug abuse. Topics include prevention and intervention, treatment, recovery support, overdose abatement, criminal justice, alcohol, and PDMPs.
Pub1: Mallatt, J. (2019). Unintended Consequences of Prescription Monitoring: Policy-Induced Substitution to Illicit Drugs. Rochester, NY. Retrieved from https://papers.ssrn.com/abstract=3418615
Pub2: Horwitz, J., Davis, C. S., McClelland, L. S., Fordon, R. S., & Meara, E. (2018). The Problem of Data Quality in Analyses of Opioid Regulation: The Case of Prescription Drug Monitoring Programs. https://doi.org/10.3386/w24947
Pub3: Meinhofer, A. (2018). Prescription Drug Monitoring Programs: The Role of Asymmetric Information on Drug Availability and Abuse. American Journal of Health Economics, 4(4), 504–526.

Label: PDAPS
Description: A national database that tracks key state laws related to prescription drug abuse. Topic areas include criminal justice, expanded access to naloxone, good samaritan 911 immunity, medical marijuana, opioid related controls, and PDMP.
Pub1: Chan, N. W., Burkhardt, J., & Flyr, M. (2020). The Effects of Recreational Marijuana Legalization and Dispensing on Opioid Mortality. Economic Inquiry, 58(2), 589–606. https://doi.org/10.1111/ecin.12819
Pub2: Kravitz-Wirtz, N., Davis, C. S., Ponicki, W. R., Rivera-Aguirre, A., Marshall, B. D. L., Martins, S. S., & Cerdá, M. (2020). Association of Medicaid Expansion With Opioid Overdose Mortality in the United States. JAMA Network Open, 3(1), e1919066. https://doi.org/10.1001/jamanetworkopen.2019.19066
Pub3: Abouk, R., Helmchen, L. A., Moghtaderi, A., & Pines, J. (2019). The ACA Medicaid Expansions and Opioid Mortality: Is There a Link? Rochester, NY. Retrieved from https://papers.ssrn.com/abstract=3368434

Label: PDMP
Description: An electronic database that tracks controlled substance prescriptions in a state in real time. Not every state has a PDMP and what information practitioners and pharmacists are required to include differ by state. The Kentucky All Schedule Prescription Electronic Reporting system, or KASPER, represents one standard of these data systems.
Pub1: Ziedan, E., & Kaestner, R. (2020). Effect of Prescription Opioids and Prescription Opioid Control Policies on Infant Health. National Bureau of Economic Research Working Paper Series, (26749). https://doi.org/10.3386/w26749
Pub2: Wang, L. X. (2020). The Complementarity of Drug Monitoring Programs and Health IT for Reducing Opioid-Related Mortality and Morbidity. Rochester, NY. Retrieved from https://papers.ssrn.com/abstract=3176809
Pub3: Brown, E., & Wehby, G. L. (2019). Economic Conditions and Drug and Opioid Overdose Deaths. Medical Care Research and Review: MCRR, 76(4), 462–477. https://doi.org/10.1177/1077558717722592
